title: 104_hr4110
content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" establishes health insurance availability for children through amendments to the Internal Revenue Code, including excise tax for failure to provide coverage and defining access requirements. The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" imposes a tax on group health plans and insurers that fail to meet coverage requirements. The tax amount is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year in which the failure occurs. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year. If the plan is self-insured, the cost of coverage is treated as the premium. No tax imposed if failure not discovered with reasonable diligence or corrected within 30 days. The tax imposed under this section does not apply to certain plans, including governmental and church plans. Liability for the tax falls on individuals who knew or should have known about the failure, with a waiver possible for failures due to reasonable cause. Liability for the tax imposed by subsection (a) falls on the group health plan for (a)(1) and the insurer for (a)(2). "Requirement of access to coverage under SEC. 9902." Group health plans must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants or beneficiaries. The offer must be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and at least annually thereafter. Insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age, residing in the US, and a citizen, national, or alien permanently residing in the US under color of law. Qualifying coverage under this section includes health care benefits that cover Medicare benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions or waiting periods. Coinsurance for part B benefits should not exceed $10 or 10% of the recognized payment amount. The payment for well child care benefits includes newborn and well-baby care, routine office visits, and pediatrician services for high-risk deliveries without deductibles, coinsurance, or copayments. The well-child care benefits cover routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, will establish a periodicity schedule for these services. Managed care is permitted without limiting provider options. The term 'qualifying young dependent' refers to an individual under 21 years old, residing in the US, a citizen or national (or alien permanently residing in the US under color of law), and a dependent as defined in section 152. "SEC. 9903. DEFINITIONS." "In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1), excluding plans with medical benefits limited to coverage in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to medical care benefits under various policies or contracts, excluding certain exceptions." The term 'health insurance coverage' excludes certain types of coverage such as accident, vision, disability income, and Medicare supplemental health insurance. The term 'health insurance coverage' excludes certain types of coverage such as accident, vision, disability income, and Medicare supplemental health insurance. Additionally, it excludes coverage provided under a group health plan, liability insurance, workers' compensation, automobile medical-payment insurance, coverage for a specified disease or illness, hospital or fixed indemnity insurance, and short-term limited duration insurance. The term 'health insurance coverage' excludes accident, vision, disability income, and Medicare supplemental health insurance. It also excludes coverage under a group health plan, liability insurance, workers' compensation, automobile medical-payment insurance, and coverage for a specified disease or illness. Additionally, it excludes hospital or fixed indemnity insurance, short-term limited duration insurance, and other comparable coverage specified in regulations. The term 'health maintenance organization' refers to federally qualified organizations, those recognized under State law, or similar organizations regulated by the State. The term 'insurer' refers to an insurance company, service, or organization licensed to do business in a State and regulated by State insurance laws. This includes health maintenance organizations recognized under State law. The term 'insurer' refers to an insurance company regulated by State insurance laws. The individual market refers to health insurance coverage for individuals, not employers. Definitions of 'beneficiary' and 'participant' are incorporated from the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Subtitle L. Health Insurance Availability for Children. The requirement of section 9902 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall take effect on January 1, 1998, and apply to coverage offered on or after that date. A refundable tax credit for the purchase of health coverage for children is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit allows individuals to claim 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. The term 'social security taxes' refers to the taxes imposed on amounts received by the taxpayer during the calendar year, subtracted from the credits allowable against tax liability. The taxpayer is entitled to a special refund of social security taxes under sections 3101 and 3201(a) on amounts received during the taxable year, including taxes on self-employment income and amounts received under section 3211(a)(1). The taxpayer may receive a special refund of social security taxes under certain conditions. Amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates can be treated as taxes. Definitions include "qualified health premium" for young dependents' health coverage. The text discusses the definition of "qualifying young dependent" in relation to health coverage and includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections. The text includes sections on purchasing health coverage for children and overpayments of tax, with amendments applying to taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
